Here is a quiz of different situations that one might consider abortion. Please take the time to think each over.
 
 How would you respond in these situations?
 
 1. A preacher and his wife are very, very poor. They already have 14 kids. Now she finds out she's pregnant with the 15th. They are living in tremendous poverty. Considering their poverty and the excessive world population, would you consider recommending she get an abortion?
 
 2. The father is sick with sniffles, the mother has TB. Of their four children, the first is blind, the second has died, the third is deaf, the fourth has TB. She finds she's pregnant again. Given this extreme situation, would you consider recommending abortion?
 
 3. A white man raped a 13-year-old black girl and she is now pregnant. If you were her parents, would you consider recommending abortion?
 
 4. A teenage girl is pregnant. She is not married. Her fiance is not the father of the baby, and her fiance is upset. Would you recommend abortion?
 
 If you answered yes to any or all of these situations:
 
 In the first case, you would have killed John wesley, one of the great evangelists in the 19th century.
 
 In the second case, you would have killed Beethoven.
 
 In the third case, you would have killed Ethel Waters, the great black gospel singer.
 
 In the fourth case, you would have declared the murder of Jesus Christ.
 
 God is the author of life, and He has given every single individual supreme value. Each life...whether inside or outside the womb, should therefore be valued by us. God knows the plans He has for each individual and has written in His book all the days ordained for us before one of them came to be. When we presume to know better than God who should be given life, we are putting ourselves in the place of God and are guilty of idolatry.
 
 Psalm 127:3 Lo, children are an heritage of the Lord: and the fruit of the womb is His reward.
 
 This quiz was written by Kirk Cameron and Ray Comfort. I thought it was interesting to think about, whether or not you are Pro-Life or Pro-Choice. Thank you for reading it.

Here is a quiz of different situations that one might consider abortion. Please take the time to think each over.
 
 How would you respond in these situations?
 
 1. A preacher and his wife are very, very poor. They already have 14 kids. Now she finds out she's pregnant with the 15th. They are living in tremendous poverty.
 
 I don't believe I have any right to impose myself into their private decisions about their family and lives. That is what choice is all about
 
 2. The father is sick with sniffles, the mother has TB. Of their four children, the first is blind, the second has died, the third is deaf, the fourth has TB. She finds she's pregnant again. Given this extreme situation, would you consider recommending abortion?
 
 Their situation--their choice. Who am I to impose what I believe upon them.
 
 3. A white man raped a 13-year-old black girl and she is now pregnant. If you were her parents, would you consider recommending abortion?
 
 Huh! If you think it's nice to force a 13-year-old to be pregnant I wonder about your moral standards!
 
 4. A teenage girl is pregnant. She is not married. Her fiance is not the father of the baby, and her fiance is upset. Would you recommend abortion?
 
 Inasmuch as the myth involved with this little situation stated that both had been made aware by the Deity of what was going on, it's none of my business. The irony of this little story is that Christians have been the most outstandingly condemning of illegitimacy and unwed mothers. They have a horrible history of cruelty and other sorts of abuse directed to these unfortunate women and their children.
 
 I also want to quote Patricia Reilly from The Religious Wounding of Women:
 
 http://www.aislingmagazine.com/aislingmagazine/articles/TAM17/Women.html
 
 "Historically, a child was considered "illegitimate" unless it bore the name of the father.
 
 "It is not enough to be born of woman."

 Really?! Here's an excerpt from How Greek Science Passed to the Arabs  
 Author De Lacy O'Leary, D.D. 
 
 

 Greek scientific thought had been in the world for a long time before it reached the Arabs, and during that period it had already spread abroad in various directions. So it is not surprising that it reached the Arabs by more than one route. It came first and in the plainest line through Christian Syriac writers, scholars, and scientists.  Then the Arabs applied themselves directly to the original Greek sources and learned over again all they had already learned, correcting and verifying earlier knowledge. Then there came a second channel of transmission indirectly through India, mathematical and astronomical work, all a good deal developed by Indian scholars, but certainly developed from material obtained from Alexandria in the first place. This material had passed to India by the sea route which connected Alexandria with north-west India. Then there was also another line of passage through India which seems to have had its beginnings in the Greek kingdom of Bactria, one of the Asiatic states founded by Alexander the Great, and a land route long kept open between the Greek world and Central Asia, especially with the city of Marw, and this perhaps connects with a Buddhist medium which at one time promoted intercourse between east and west, though Buddhism as a religion was withdrawing to the Far East when the Arabs reached Central Asia. [pages 2-3].

Here is a quiz of different situations that one might consider abortion. Please take the time to think each over.
 
 How would you respond in these situations?
 
 1. A preacher and his wife are very, very poor. They already have 14 kids. Now she finds out she's pregnant with the 15th. They are living in tremendous poverty. Considering their poverty and the excessive world population, would you consider recommending she get an abortion?
 
 2. The father is sick with sniffles, the mother has TB. Of their four children, the first is blind, the second has died, the third is deaf, the fourth has TB. She finds she's pregnant again. Given this extreme situation, would you consider recommending abortion?
 
 3. A white man raped a 13-year-old black girl and she is now pregnant. If you were her parents, would you consider recommending abortion?
 
 4. A teenage girl is pregnant. She is not married. Her fiance is not the father of the baby, and her fiance is upset. Would you recommend abortion?
 
 If you answered yes to any or all of these situations:
 
 In the first case, you would have killed John wesley, one of the great evangelists in the 19th century.
 
 In the second case, you would have killed Beethoven.
 
 In the third case, you would have killed Ethel Waters, the great black gospel singer.
 
 In the fourth case, you would have declared the murder of Jesus Christ.
 
 God is the author of life, and He has given every single individual supreme value. Each life...whether inside or outside the womb, should therefore be valued by us. God knows the plans He has for each individual and has written in His book all the days ordained for us before one of them came to be. When we presume to know better than God who should be given life, we are putting ourselves in the place of God and are guilty of idolatry.
 
 Psalm 127:3 Lo, children are an heritage of the Lord: and the fruit of the womb is His reward.
 
 This quiz was written by Kirk Cameron and Ray Comfort. I thought it was interesting to think about, whether or not you are Pro-Life or Pro-Choice. Thank you for reading it.

 
 
 The whole point of being pro-choice is that you suport what the women chooses. We don't tell women to get abortions, we support women who choose to on thier own. It's the "rights to liferers" who tell people how to live thier lives.

the only problem with the pro-choice side is the SLOGANISM into which the position devolved. People take the issue of choice and they say "It's all about choice." It's not all about only choice. Choice comes because and only because there are other moral considerations.
 
 You wouldn't be able to get an abortion if the being inside of you were capable of doing differential calculus and living on its own, and being self-aware.
 
 the only reason why choice is even an issue is because the idea that a Fetus is equal to a normal person's value is laughable.

.....
 You need to be reminded that America, and most other countries, were founded not on killing fetuses that aren't even "people" yet, but actual children, women, and men, many of whom were innocent of any legal or political grievance. America, for example, is land built on the destruction of the Native American population. It was atheists and christians, killing hand in hand, to forge a land of our own...founded on the blood of others.

 -Mach

 
 Yeah, I guess our European heritage brought out the worst in us.

Here is a quiz of different situations that one might consider abortion. Please take the time to think each over.
 
 How would you respond in these situations?
 
 1. A preacher and his wife are very, very poor. They already have 14 kids. Now she finds out she's pregnant with the 15th. They are living in tremendous poverty. Considering their poverty and the excessive world population, would you consider recommending she get an abortion?

 
 If he's a preacher and wife, then that just poses more questions. Does he have a pastoral following? (A flock, a church...) If so, are they not supportive?
 
 This question of yours is simply too vague.
 
 
2. The father is sick with sniffles, the mother has TB. Of their four children, the first is blind, the second has died, the third is deaf, the fourth has TB. She finds she's pregnant again. Given this extreme situation, would you consider recommending abortion?

 
 First off, "the sniffles" doesn't exactly equal a life threatening situation. The TB the mother has does! There is a high risk of her infecting everyone else in the family or who comes in close contact with her without treatment. Also, if the second kid died, then you can't say there are four children...there are only three. One would wonder what living conditions this family is in as well we genetic background to have one deaf child and one blind. The kid with TB needs treatment as does the mother. Given your discription, I might recommend abortion until she can get a better grip on her life.
 
 
 
3. A white man raped a 13-year-old black girl and she is now pregnant. If you were her parents, would you consider recommending abortion?

 
 Your usage of racial identifications in this example are only meant to confuse the issue. They are of little to no importance. 
 A thirteen year old child should NEVER have to suffer with the burdon of an unwanted pregnancy, ESPECIALLY from a rape!
 Yes! If she and her family (being that she is under age and does not fully have the capacity to make these kinds of decisions) feel an abortion is their solution, then it's their desicion.
 
 
 
4. A teenage girl is pregnant. She is not married. Her fiance is not the father of the baby, and her fiance is upset. Would you recommend abortion?

 
 She's a teenager? What is she doing being engaged in the first place? 
 Honey, if she's so backwater as to be engaged as a teenager in this day and age and she is so irresponcible as to be sexually active with multiple partners...yes...abortion is recommended along with the option of adoption. But I really don't think she is ready to be a good parent.
 
 
 
If you answered yes to any or all of these situations:
 
 In the first case, you would have killed John wesley, one of the great evangelists in the 19th century.

 
 Well right there, you used an oxymoron, "Great" and "Evangelist" got together about as well as Military Inteligence.
 Secondly, as I stated before...you left too many other questions unanswered about the "Preacher." 
 
 
 
In the second case, you would have killed Beethoven.
 Again, misleading questions will give you subjective answers.
 
 
 
In the third case, you would have killed Ethel Waters, the great black gospel singer.

 
 Oh well. Life goes on.
 
 
In the fourth case, you would have declared the murder of Jesus Christ.

 
 Well first off, again, you asked a misleading question. Jesus didn't just happen in the last century, nor in the last decade. Besides, God Rapes an unmarried Jew and gets away with a violent crime?!?
 And people wonder why I'm such a skeptic.
 I've never bought the whole "emaculate conception" jazz to begin with.
 
 
 
God is the author of life, and He has given every single individual supreme value. Each life...whether inside or outside the womb, should therefore be valued by us. God knows the plans He has for each individual and has written in His book all the days ordained for us before one of them came to be. When we presume to know better than God who should be given life, we are putting ourselves in the place of God and are guilty of idolatry.

 
 Hmmm...there's a twist..Myself as God!! WOW!!! I never would have been so arrogant as to think so, but since you insist...COOL!!! 
 
 
 
Psalm 127:3 Lo, children are an heritage of the Lord: and the fruit of the womb is His reward.

 
 Sweet sentiment, especially when there were only a few thousand bodies on the planet to begin with. Honey, times change..we're over SIX BILLION NOW!!! Welcome to the Twenty-first century!

I disagree. Regardless of what the fetus is, it can not force the woman to give of her bodily resources to sustain its life. A person bleeding to death or dying from kidney failure can not force you to give of your bodily resources to keep them alive. Neither can the fetus.
 
 So essentially, the status of the fetus is irrelevant. The only thing that matters is whether pregnant women should be denied the bodily integrity that prevents the rest of us from being forced to give blood against our will. Is she less of a person, less of a human being because she is pregnant? Does the fetus have rights that no living, born, sentient person holds, the right to forcible extract people's bodily resources against that person's will?
 
 That really is what it comes down to.

As for Pol Pot and Stalin, lets not include mass murdering f***heads who just happened to be atheist as opposed to those killed in the name of atheism.

 I'll just interject my opinion about abortion for no apparent purpose. I'm afraid I'm a true fence sitter when it comes to abortion. Every human, or every individual animal for that matter, is an individual because they have a unique genetic makeup. At the moment of conception, a new individual is created. The single-celled zygote is a human individual. It is a human life, if you will. It's not a particularly viable form of human life, but it is still an individual human. So abortion is truly the killing of a human individual. The reason I sit on the fence is because I cannot bring myself to consider this a murder. And, sadly, I can find no good dividing line to judge when the abortion is a murder and when it is not. I'm just glad I'm not a Supreme Court Justice. I wouldn't want to be forced to make that decision.

 I'm Pro-Choice because I believe it's every woman's choice to do with her body as she so chooses. If you had bothered to notice, I have never had an abortion and have the son to prove it. Therefore I am not "pro-abortion" as a means of birth control. I'm an avid promoter of contraseption, but if a woman is raped, it's no one's business but her own. If a girl is impregnated by a family memeber/ie incest, it's her body not her families! If a woman who, for her own reasons has found herself in a situation where continuing a pregnancy would be detrimental to her own health, it's her decision...NOT anyone elses.
 Personally, I feel the Catholic Church is way out of line by banning any and all forms of contraseption/protection. I firmly believe in education and distribution of condoms anywhere men and women/boys and girls/ guys and gals, congregate publicly. I believe insurence companies should cover "the pill" in prescription coverages. (Not only for it's contraseption uses, but for it's hormone ballencing properties)
 
 I do not promote abortion as a catch-all form of birth control. 
 
 So don't assume the two terms of "pro-abortion" and "pro-choice" are in anyway interchangable. They are not.
 
 
 BTW - As a MAN you don't get a say in what ANY woman does or does not do with HER body....YOU DO NOT OWN WOMEN! PERIOD, no "if's", "and's" or "but's" about it!
